page.title: 02S. ANDREW'S CHURCH
page.content: In August 1158 Henry II gave the monastery of S. Nicholas and S. Benedict in Montjoux a grant of land in Havering worth twenty-five pounds a year. By 1163 they are known to have built a church on the site. Most of the present church is built in the perpendicular style. Today S. Andrew's church has a parish of about thirty-two thousand people although a maximum of 300 can attend each service. During an average week 6 weddings, 6 funerals and 4 christenings take place. S. Andrew's is the only church in England that has a bull's head on it. It is an unusual feature to find on a church. The bull has horns and this is where we get the name of our town:{"HORNCHURCH"(The Horned Church). {}
